title: Indemsy rated the top dog in market
subtitle: Indemsy flight compensation website is earning profits out of the charts
content:
Every year, millions of passengers board flights with one simple expectation ‚Äî to arrive at their destination on time. But the reality of modern air travel tells a very different story. Delays stretch into hours. Flights get canceled without warning. Passengers are bumped from seats they paid for, left stranded in terminals with nothing but a voucher and a vague apology. What most travelers don't realize is that they are often legally entitled to significant financial compensation ‚Äî and the airlines are counting on them never finding out.

That's exactly the gap Indemsy was built to close.

Since our founding, we have helped thousands of air passengers claim the money they were owed ‚Äî money that airlines would have quietly kept if no one had pushed back. To date, our clients have recovered over a million dollars in compensation, and that number grows every single day. Not because we got lucky. Because we know the rules, we know the process, and we know how to fight on behalf of the people who fly.

The laws protecting air passengers are surprisingly strong. Regulations across the United States, European Union, and many other jurisdictions require airlines to compensate passengers for significant delays, cancellations, and denied boarding caused by circumstances within the airline's control. Depending on the route and the length of the delay, a single passenger can be entitled to hundreds of dollars in compensation. The problem is that airlines make the claims process complicated on purpose. They use legal language designed to confuse, create barriers that discourage follow-through, and often deny valid claims outright, betting that most passengers will simply give up.

Most do. But Indemsy clients don't.

Our team handles everything from start to finish. You tell us what happened ‚Äî your flight number, your route, the date of your disruption ‚Äî and we take it from there. We evaluate your claim, determine what you're owed under applicable law, and file on your behalf. If the airline pushes back, we push harder. We've seen nearly every tactic airlines use to delay or deny legitimate claims, and we know exactly how to respond. Our clients don't need to understand aviation law or spend weeks writing back-and-forth emails with airline customer service departments. That's our job.

What makes Indemsy different from simply filing a complaint yourself isn't just experience ‚Äî it's leverage. Airlines know that individual passengers are unlikely to escalate a dispute to the point where it costs the airline more to fight than to settle. When Indemsy is involved, that calculation changes entirely. We are persistent, we are thorough, and we don't back down. The airlines know it. That's why our clients see results that they never would have achieved on their own.

We work on a no-win, no-fee basis. If we don't recover compensation for you, you don't pay us anything. This isn't a gamble for our clients ‚Äî it's a promise that we only take on cases we believe in, and that our incentives are perfectly aligned with yours. We win when you win. It's that simple.

The passengers we help aren't frequent flyers gaming a system. They're families who missed a wedding because their connecting flight was canceled. Business travelers who lost a critical day of work sitting in an airport gate. Solo travelers who were told their seat was overbooked and there was nothing the airline could do. There was always something that could be done. Indemsy is that something.

Air travel is not going to get less complicated. Airlines are not going to start making it easy to claim the compensation you're owed. But with the right advocate in your corner, the frustration of a disrupted flight doesn't have to be the end of the story. For over a million dollars in recovered compensation and counting, it was just the beginning.

title: Neuroscientist resigns from Columbia amid revelations about Epstein ties
content:
Dr Richard Axel, a molecular biologist and Nobel laureate, has announced that he is stepping down as the leader of a prestigious neuroscience institute at Columbia University over his ties to Jeffrey Epstein.

Axel, who has taught at Columbia for 53 years, said in a statement on Tuesday that he would be leaving his post as co-director of the university‚Äôs Zuckerman Mind Brain Behavior Institute to ‚Äúfocus on research and teaching in my lab‚Äù.

‚ÄúMy past association with Jeffrey Epstein was a serious error in judgment, which I deeply regret. I apologize for compromising the trust of my friends, students, and colleagues,‚Äù Axel wrote.

‚ÄúI recognize the problems this has caused, and I will work to restore this trust. What has emerged about Epstein‚Äôs appalling conduct, the harm that he has caused to so many people, makes my association with him all the more painful and inexcusable.‚Äù

The latest publication of the Epstein files, in which more than 3m documents were released relating to the late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, reveal a multi-year relationship between Axel and the disgraced New York financier.

Publicly released correspondence between Axel and Epstein spans at least nine years, from 2010 to 2019, notably after Epstein‚Äôs 2008 conviction for soliciting prostitution from a minor. Axel‚Äôs name appears in the files more than 900 times, as previously reported by the Columbia Spectator.

The files include a 30 December 2011, one-way ticket for Axel and his wife, Cornelia Bargmann, to St Thomas, Virgin Islands, which is typically seen as the usual jumping-off point to reach Epstein‚Äôs nearby private island, Little St James, by helicopter.

The ticket was later voided, according to the Columbia Spectator, and a university spokesperson confirmed to the outlet that Axel and his wife never visited Epstein‚Äôs island.

In a separate statement made on Tuesday, Columbia University said that the school ‚Äúhas seen no evidence that Dr Axel violated any University policy or the law‚Äù.

The university said that they agreed with Axel‚Äôs decision to resign, ‚Äúwhile at the same time recognizing his extraordinary contributions to the University and his dedication to his colleagues, to his students, and to science‚Äù.

The resignation is the latest as institutions of higher education across the country grapple with the fallout of the Epstein files. Epstein wielded his money and influence across various industries, but he had a strong interest in academia, maintaining decades-long relationships with board members, professors and administrators everywhere from Harvard to the University of California, Los Angeles to Ohio State University.

Axel won the Nobel prize for physiology or medicine in 2004 alongside Linda B Buck, for their research identifying genes that allow humans to detect more than 10,000 different smells.

In his statement, Axel also announced that he would be stepping down as an investigator at the Howard Hughes Medical Institute, a prestigious biomedical research organization.
subtitle: Nobel laureate Richard Axel announced resignation as co-director of Columbia University‚Äôs neuroscience institute

title: Wellness influencer picked by Trump for surgeon general faces Senate grilling
content:
Casey Means, Donald Trump‚Äôs nominee for surgeon general of the United States, appeared before lawmakers on the Senate committee for health, labor and pensions on Wednesday, after her initial confirmation hearing was postponed in October when she went into labor hours before she was set to testify.

Means is the president‚Äôs controversial pick for the role of the nation‚Äôs top doctor, responsible for disseminating the latest public health guidance.

Democrats on the committee quickly expressed their concerns about Means‚Äôs ability to push back against Kennedy‚Äôs misinformation about the safety and efficacy of vaccines, which public health experts says is endangering the wellbeing of the American public.

‚ÄúI have very serious questions about the ability of Dr Means to be the kind of surgeon general this country needs,‚Äù said Senator Bernie Sanders, the committee‚Äôs ranking member.

Although Means graduated from Stanford School of Medicine, she did not complete her head and neck surgical residency at Oregon Health and Science University, is not board-certified, and does not have an active medical license. Her scientific experience is mainly focused around her work as a wellness influencer, and a leader within the Make America Healthy Again (Maha) space ‚Äì which has become the key pillar of the Trump administration‚Äôs health policy under Robert F Kennedy Jr.

Means declined to give a simple yes-or-no answer when the committee chair, Republican senator Bill Cassidy, pressed her on whether, as surgeon general, she would encourage parents to vaccinate their children with routine shots such as the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) vaccine.

‚ÄúI‚Äôm supportive of vaccination. I do believe that each patient, mother, parent, needs to have a conversation with their pediatrician about any medication they‚Äôre putting in their body and their children‚Äôs bodies,‚Äù Means said.

When Cassidy asked whether she would state her position more clearly if confirmed, she replied: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm not an individual‚Äôs doctor, and every individual needs to talk to their doctor before putting a medication in their body.‚Äù

Means‚Äôs comments come as measles outbreaks continue across the country, with South Carolina experiencing the worst measles outbreak in more than 30 years amid declining childhood immunization rates. In response, Mehmet Oz, the administrator of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services (CMS), urged Americans to ‚Äútake the vaccine, please‚Äù earlier this month. In an interview with CNN, Oz issued a rare plea from the Trump administration to insist upon inoculation. ‚ÄúNot all illnesses are equally dangerous and not all people are equally susceptible to those illnesses,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúBut measles is one you should get your vaccine.‚Äù

While Means insisted that anti-vaccine rhetoric ‚Äúhas never been a part‚Äù of her message and said she was ‚Äúnot here to complicate the issue on vaccines‚Äù, she repeatedly sidestepped direct questions from lawmakers about whether vaccines cause autism ‚Äì a theory long discredited by the scientific community and promoted by health secretary Kennedy.

‚ÄúThe reality is that we have an autism crisis that‚Äôs increasing, and this is devastating to many families, and we do not know as a medical community what causes autism,‚Äù she said, while acknowledging that there is an overwhelming body of evidence refuting claims that vaccines cause the condition. ‚ÄúI also think that science is never settled, and I think that the effort to look at comprehensive, cumulative exposures into what is causing autism is important.‚Äù

Means has spurned the medical establishment, noting that she dropped out of her residency because she grew ‚Äúdisillusioned with traditional healthcare‚Äù, which, she claims, focuses on diagnoses and prescriptions instead of diet and lifestyle.

During her opening remarks before lawmakers, she praised Trump and Kennedy for inviting ‚Äúa mature, candid, grand conversation about how our medical education and fixing perverse incentives can pull us back from the brink‚Äù.

In 2024, Means co-authored a book, Good Energy, with her older brother Calley, an entrepreneur who currently serves as one of Kennedy‚Äôs close advisers and has also railed against the US medical establishment. The siblings argue in their book that metabolic health is the key to reversing chronic illness, a framing that critics say verges into pseudoscience. ‚ÄúMany doctors are doing the wrong things, pushing pills and interventions when an ultra-aggressive stance on diet and behavior would do far more for the patient in front of them,‚Äù Means writes in the book.

The prospective surgeon general also co‚Äëfounded Levels, a health tracking company built around continuous glucose monitoring, as part of her belief that people need real‚Äëtime data to understand what‚Äôs driving their symptoms.

In the past, Means has trodden lightly when it comes to the efficacy of vaccines, she is aligned with Kennedy‚Äôs routine skepticism of the number of vaccines children are recommended.

‚ÄúI also find it perplexing that people are often shamed for asking any questions about the 70+ injected medications going into their children‚Äôs bodies before the age of 18,‚Äù she wrote on her website. ‚ÄúI am not making a statement about the utility of vaccines; I am making a statement about an $80bn industry getting to have legal immunity from wrongdoing and having the American population in a chokehold that forces them to comply with the complete schedule or face consequences.‚Äù

Earlier this year, the Trump administration announced it would slash routine vaccine recommendations during childhood from 17 to 11 jabs, a move that public health experts said would erode trust in inoculations and allow infectious diseases to spread.

Means‚Äôs nomination has received significant backlash from the US scientific community. Former surgeon general Richard Carmona, who served under George W Bush, told the Guardian that Means‚Äôs nomination was a ‚Äúdisgrace‚Äù to the future of America‚Äôs public health system. ‚ÄúShe has no significant public health background experience. She has no scalable leadership experience,‚Äù he said.

Under Kennedy‚Äôs leadership, the Department of Health and Human Services (HHS) has been beset with chaos. Grants have been terminated, there has been a mass exodus of officials from key agencies, and anti-vaccine loyalists have been installed to the advisory committee on immunization practices (ACIP). Cassidy, the Louisiana Republican who ultimately cast the deciding vote to confirm Kennedy as Trump‚Äôs health secretary last year, did so despite expressing concern about Kennedy‚Äôs anti‚Äëvaccine record. Kennedy assured him during the confirmation process that he would not interfere with the make-up of the ACIP. He has since reversed course, reshaping the department and sidelining career public‚Äëhealth experts.

Last year, the Senate-confirmed director of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Susan Monarez, was ousted from her role less than a month after starting. In September, she told health committee senators that she was forced out of the CDC for her unwillingness to comply with Kennedy‚Äôs vaccine agenda. This month there was even more turnover at the CDC when Jim O‚ÄôNeill, Monarez‚Äôs replacement, left the agency. His number two, principal deputy director Ralph Abraham, stepped down from his position this week.

Means is Trump‚Äôs second nominee for the surgeon general position. Last year he put forward Dr Janette Nesheiwat, but withdrew her name before her Senate confirmation hearing amid criticism from the right and reports of misleading medical credentials.

Carmona said that his optimism that lawmakers will push back against Means‚Äôs credentials was ‚Äúmuted‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe see too much ideology and not enough science,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre putting an untrained person in the position ‚Ä¶ at a time when we probably need a real leader more than ever because of the mis- and disinformation that‚Äôs out there.‚Äù
subtitle: Critics concerned as Casey Means, aligned with RFK Jr on vaccine stance, does not have active medical licence

title: Diageo slashes dividend and vows to address Guinness shortage in London
content:
Diageo has slashed its dividend and cut its annual sales and profit forecast for the second time in four months, as the maker of Guinness warned of capacity constraints affecting drinkers of ‚Äúthe black stuff‚Äù in London pubs.

The world‚Äôs largest spirits maker ‚Äì which owns brands including Smirnoff vodka, Johnnie Walker whisky and Don Julio tequila ‚Äì lost more than ¬£5bn of its market value on Wednesday as it reported weak demand in the US and China in the first results released under the new chief executive, Sir Dave Lewis.

The former Tesco chief executive, who earned the nickname ‚ÄúDrastic Dave‚Äù as a result of his cost-cutting during almost three decades at the conglomerate Unilever, took the reins at Diageo in January and wasted no time in cutting the company‚Äôs shareholder dividend in his attempt to turn around the drinks maker.

Related: BrewDog sale plan leaves some ‚Äòequity punk‚Äô investors steaming

Describing his first seven weeks in the role as ‚Äúpretty intense‚Äù, Lewis said in a results webcast it had not been a simple choice to reduce the dividend, halving it to 20 cents a share, down from 40.5 cents a year ago.

‚ÄúThis is not an easy decision to make, but we believe it is the right one. The North American market is challenged,‚Äù Lewis said.

‚ÄúOur portfolio needs some time and investment to make it more competitive. At the same time, we need to invest in our business, specifically in its capacity and capability.‚Äù

Lewis has joined London-based Diageo at a time when it is struggling with the impact of Donald Trump‚Äôs tariffs, squeezed household finances and consumer shifts, amid the rise in use of GLP-1 weight loss jabs and lifestyle changes as many younger people choose to drink little or no alcohol.

His appointment, after a four-month recruitment drive by the company, followed the abrupt resignation last July of Debra Crew, during whose tenure Diageo struggled with lacklustre performance and investor disquiet.

Diageo‚Äôs shares were boosted after the announcement of Lewis‚Äôs appointment last November but dropped by nearly 13% on Wednesday, making it the biggest faller on the FTSE 100.

It came as the company said it expected organic sales to fall between 2% and 3% in 2026, while it forecast its organic operating profit to remain flat.

Lewis said consumption of Diageo‚Äôs spirits remained fairly stable despite the use of GLP-1 drugs such as Mounjaro and Wegovy but added that consumers were increasingly choosing to have fewer drinks each time they indulged.

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs the serves-per-occasion where we see the change,‚Äù Lewis said. ‚ÄúWhat you see is a very significant squeeze on disposable income.‚Äù

The company intends to respond to squeezed consumer finances by offering smaller packs, Lewis said.

Pressure on consumer finances has also resulted in US drinkers buying less tequila, particularly Diageo‚Äôs Don Julio and Casamigos brands, as they opted instead for cheaper options.

Praising Guinness as a ‚Äúphenomenal asset‚Äù, which Lewis said was the fastest-growing beer brand in North America, he said it continued to face challenges.

‚ÄúIf you‚Äôve tried to buy a pint in London, you also know that we have some capacity constraints, too. This capacity and geographical constraint is an issue that we need to address, and quickly,‚Äù he said.

Guinness, once viewed as an ‚Äúold man‚Äôs drink‚Äù, has soared in popularity on social media in recent years, and has been adopted by younger drinkers and female celebrities including Kim Kardashian and Olivia Rodrigo.

However, soaring sales left the company at times unable to meet demand, and supply problems have persisted, especially in London, where Diageo opened a Guinness experience venue in late 2025. It expects to welcome half a million visitors this year.

Dan Coatsworth, the head of markets at the broker AJ Bell, said: ‚ÄúGuinness is a bright spot in an otherwise gloomy update and means Diageo‚Äôs results aren‚Äôt a complete mess.

‚ÄúLewis must like a spectacular challenge, as it was clear from the day he was offered the job that it wouldn‚Äôt be easy. Fixing Diageo is like turning around an oil tanker ‚Äì a very slow process.‚Äù
subtitle: Drinks maker reduces sales and profit forecast for second time in four months amid weak demand in US and China

title: ‚ÄòNobel prize for fiction‚Äô: Trump‚Äôs State of the Union provokes polarized reactions
content:
Congressional Democrats lined up on Tuesday night to call Donald Trump a liar and Republicans said America had never been greater. The country‚Äôs longest-ever State of the Union address had ended, and the two parties had, again, watched entirely different speeches.

Trump‚Äôs address ran for more than two hours, with the president touching on tariffs, border security, military recruitment and energy production, among other topics. He told the country the economy was booming, inflation was under control and a golden age was at hand, but Democrats were not persuaded.

‚ÄúDonald Trump told us that the economy is ‚Äòwonderful‚Äô and that everything is ‚Äòaffordable‚Äô,‚Äù said Representative Brad Sherman, a Democrat from California. ‚ÄúAnd if you believe that, then you probably believe he was faithful to all three of his wives.‚Äù Sherman also said the address was ‚Äúthe longest and worst State of the Union in our country‚Äôs history‚Äù.

Related: Why the longest-ever State of the Union address was the most inconsequential

Representative Jim McGovern of Massachusetts suggested the sheer volume of falsehoods was itself the strategy. ‚ÄúIf any other president had spun out of thin air such a grandiose, absurd lie about their economic record, it would have been a huge scandal,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúTrump‚Äôs strategy is to flood the zone with so much BS that it‚Äôs impossible to keep up. Don‚Äôt give up on the truth.‚Äù

Senator Chris Coons of Delaware said the president had missed his moment. ‚ÄúPresident Trump had the chance to bring the country together tonight. Instead, we got a campaign rally where he lied, ducked responsibility and had zero answers for Americans worried about the challenges they‚Äôre facing.‚Äù

Trump‚Äôs tariff agenda featured prominently in the address, in which he framed it as the foundation of an industrial revival. But Senator Mark Kelly of Arizona doubted that his constituents had heard anything of use. ‚ÄúOne year into his presidency, families are paying more at the grocery store. Seniors are struggling to afford their prescription drugs. Small business owners are having trouble keeping their doors open, and President Trump‚Äôs illegal tariffs are making it worse.‚Äù

Representative Raul Ruiz of California went through the speech‚Äôs claims one by one. ‚ÄúHe lied to us about inflation, while his tariffs have increased costs for all of us. He lied to us about healthcare, while his policies took away health coverage from millions of Americans. He lied to us about protecting retirees, while he is doing everything he can to dismantle social security and Medicare.‚Äù

Ruiz added: ‚ÄúTrump wants desperately a Nobel prize ‚Äì with all his lies, he should try to get one for fiction.‚Äù

Senator Raphael Warnock of Georgia said: ‚ÄúTheir proudest accomplishment is taking food away from working families to give their donors another tax cut.‚Äù

Related: Jobs, gas prices and ending wars: factchecking Trump‚Äôs State of the Union claims

The mood in the chamber was similarly testy during the speech. Representative Al Green of Texas was escorted out after holding up a sign reading ‚ÄúBlack people aren‚Äôt apes!‚Äù Representative Ilhan Omar of Minnesota shouted ‚ÄúYou have killed Americans‚Äù at the president, and Representative Rashida Tlaib of Michigan was heard calling out: ‚ÄúRelease the Epstein files.‚Äù

On the Republican side, the mood was different. Trump had claimed gains on the border, falling crime, record military recruitment and a reviving economy, and his party took him at his word, and backed him up.

Representative Byron Donalds of Florida posted on X immediately after the address: ‚ÄúIn just ONE YEAR, we have achieved a transformation like NO OTHER. Economy BOOMING. Inflation UNDER CONTROL. Border SECURED. Military recruitment at RECORD LEVELS. Crime DOWN. PEACE THROUGH STRENGTH. The Golden Age of America is upon us.‚Äù

Senator Markwayne Mullin of Oklahoma singled out the moment Trump challenged members of Congress to stand if they believed the government‚Äôs first duty was to protect American citizens rather than undocumented migrants. ‚ÄúThe contrast was clear,‚Äù Mullin wrote. ‚ÄúPresident Trump is an America First fighter, and a fearless patriot.‚Äù

Representative Tony Wied of Wisconsin pointed to the manufacturing theme running through the address. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs time that we re-industrialize our great country and really ignite our manufacturing base,‚Äù he said in an interview on C-Span. ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs what the president is focused on, that‚Äôs what House Republicans are focused on. I think we‚Äôre moving in the right direction.‚Äù

Representative Jason Smith called it ‚Äúthe strongest State of the Union Address I‚Äôve attended‚Äù, saying Trump‚Äôs vision ‚Äúfosters patriotism, defends American citizens, and will deliver another year of historic results‚Äù.

Many Democrats highlighted the distance between that version of events and the daily lives for their constituents. Representative Luz Rivas of California, in a post in Spanish, said families in her district were ‚Äúfeeling the impact of high prices and the presence of ICE in our communities‚Äù and that she and her colleagues would ‚Äúcontinue fighting to hold the Trump administration accountable for all the chaos they have caused in our country‚Äù.

Representative Adelita Grijalva of Arizona summed up the evening up for her party: ‚ÄúThat was two hours of rambling completely detached from reality. Just over a year into his presidency, America is less safe, more divided and more expensive than ever before.‚Äù
subtitle: Democrats accuse president‚Äôs address of litany of lies as Republicans hail his bullish claims about year back in office

title: Source close to Rolling Stones disputes Melania producer‚Äôs claim Mick Jagger ‚Äògave his blessing‚Äô to use song
content:
A source close to Mick Jagger has cast doubt on a claim by Melania producer Marc Beckman that his team was closely involved with the singer over the use of a Rolling Stones song in the film.

The film, which follows the first lady in the 20 days leading up to Donald Trump‚Äôs second inauguration in January 2025, opens with a sequence in Mar-a-Lago soundtracked to the Rolling Stones‚Äô Gimme Shelter. Despite being owned by music company ABKCO, Beckman told Variety that Jagger ‚Äúwas actually involved‚Äù and ‚Äúgave us his blessing‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe worked very close with them on that,‚Äù Beckman continued. ‚ÄúAnd that wasn‚Äôt a political thing. With the Stones, they were just like, ‚ÄòOh, you‚Äôre making a nice movie.‚Äô They were like able to get over the hurdle. It‚Äôs not politics ‚Äì it‚Äôs just some story about some woman that is going from being a civilian back into the White House, and this movie looks cool and Brett [Ratner] is doing a cool job and Melania Trump is focused, and let‚Äôs do it. We showed it to them and they were impressed.‚Äù

Speaking off the record, the source close to Jagger said he felt scepticism was necessary as the producer was attempting to promote the movie. A spokesperson for the Rolling Stones also told the Guardian the deal to use Gimme Shelter in the film was made exclusively between rights holders ABKCO and Melania‚Äôs producers, and that the band had nothing to do with it.

The Rolling Stones are among those artists who have previously objected to the use of their songs in rallies for Donald Trump. Others include Guns N‚Äô Roses. Grace Jones, the estate of Prince, Neil Young, Bruce Springsteen, Adele, Queen, REM, Elton John, Abba, Jack White, C√©line Dion, the Foo Fighters and the estates of Isaac Hayes and Tom Petty.

Beckman also told Variety that the first three of these had also been approached with a view to using their music on Melania, but refused on political grounds.

He clarified that the members of Guns N‚Äô Roses were split on the decision, which needed to be unanimous, while Jones ‚Äúapparently couldn‚Äôt get over the political hurdle, notwithstanding the fact that the film is not a political film‚Äù. While the rights holders to the Prince song requested were reportedly in favour of it being used, the lawyer managing his estate vetoed the request, saying: ‚ÄúPrince would never want his song associated with Donald Trump.‚Äù

Beckman said that he protested that the film was ‚Äúnot a Donald Trump film! He comes into the movie once in a while, but this is all about Melania. It‚Äôs not political. And that guy blocked it. It‚Äôs so ridiculous.‚Äù

The Village People anthem YMCA is a staple of Trump rallies and features on the Melania soundtrack, as does Billie Jean by Michael Jackson, which Melania says is her favourite song by her favourite artist.

As well as Jackson‚Äôs version, the audience hears an impromptu cover by the first lady and Ratner as they duet on the tune in the back of a limo.

In the Variety interview, Beckman ‚Äì who has been an adviser to Melania Trump for 25 years ‚Äì also discussed the impasse over use of a song from Jonny Greenwood‚Äôs soundtrack to Phantom Thread. Greenwood and director Paul Thomas Anderson requested the removal of the track, citing a lack of notice given to Greenwood by rights owner Universal. The music currently remains in Ratner‚Äôs film and Beckman said he believed it would stay so ‚Äúfor ever, regardless of the infrastructure which delivers the content‚Äù.

Beckman attributed Greenwood‚Äôs distaste to ‚Äújust part of the unfortunate time we‚Äôre living in. We went out and created a nice film that doesn‚Äôt get into any kind of political policy or anything like that.‚Äù He also said the row had not dinted his fandom for Radiohead, saying he would continued to ‚Äúlisten to their music every single day‚Äù.

Amazon paid $40m (¬£29.6m) for the rights to Melania and spent $35m (¬£25.9m) on marketing. The film opened earlier this month and has so far made around $16.4m (¬£12.1m) worldwide, 98% of which comes from its US take.

The film scored a better-than-expected $7m (¬£5.2m) in the US on its first weekend of release before falling 67% in its second week. In the UK it opened at No 29 before falling 88% week-on-week to No 62. No showtimes are currently available for the film in the UK.

Beckman addressed the record-breaking disparity between the film‚Äôs critics rating on aggregate site Rotten Tomatoes and the scores given to the films by audience members (who could verify a ticket purchase via Fandango).

‚ÄúWhat really is a critic‚Äôs job today?‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs worse than bias. It‚Äôs like they‚Äôre voting, with political ideology first. There were some critiques I read that didn‚Äôt even talk about the film; they only spoke about President Trump. That‚Äôs just unfortunately where we are today in society.‚Äù
subtitle: Spokesperson for Rolling Stones tells Guardian band did not liaise with Marc Beckman and his team on use of Gimme Shelter in first lady documentary

title: Jean Wilson obituary
content:
On 5 January 1950, Jean Wilson, who has died aged 103, inaugurated her charity, the British Empire Society for the Blind, answering the phone to journalists with ‚ÄúWhich department would you like?‚Äù in a bid to conceal that it was such a tiny, two-person operation.

Founded with her husband, John, and renamed Sightsavers in 1986, from these acorn beginnings it became a leading charity tackling blindness in developing countries. Today each year it funds more than 9m eye examinations and half a million sight-saving operations in 30 countries.

Aged 19, Jean McDermid, as she was then, met John Wilson in 1943 when he lodged in her family home in Eastcote, west London. The couple, who married in 1944, shared a radical vision to help the millions of people globally affected by blindness.

In the 1940s John, who was blind himself, after an explosion in a school chemistry lesson when he was 12, worked for the National Institute for the Blind (now the RNIB). In 1946-47 he participated in a government tour of British colonial territories in Africa and the Middle East, and was appalled at the sheer number of people who were blind due to avoidable causes such as disease, malnutrition and lack of medicines. Determined to help, he quit his job and the couple set up their charity and started fundraising.

Theirs was a tight-knit double-act and their skills dovetailed. They travelled tirelessly, with Wilson acting as her husband‚Äôs ‚Äúeyes‚Äù. She was a talented photographer, fundraiser and communicator, persuading politicians including Lord Halifax, the former foreign secretary, and well-known blind people such as Helen Keller to support them.

In 1950, one of their first trips was to the Gold Coast (now Ghana). They visited the Nakong area on the River Sisili, a hotspot for the parasitic disease onchocerciasis. Transmitted by tiny flies that breed near the river and bite humans, the parasites burrow into the body causing permanent sight loss.

Nakong was known as ‚Äúthe country of the blind‚Äù and Wilson said: ‚ÄúIt was awful, a place of horror.‚Äù Most villagers over the age of 12 were blind, so they had to feel their way along hemp ropes to reach the well or get their children to lead them. Thinking ahead about how to fundraise ‚Äì the disease has been treatable since the 1980s with the drug ivermectin ‚Äì Wilson knew the name was a stumbling block.

She said to her husband: ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs no good calling this thing onchocerciasis. If I can‚Äôt pronounce it or spell it, I certainly can‚Äôt raise funds for it. It comes from the river, so let‚Äôs call it ‚Äòriver blindness‚Äô.‚Äù The name immediately caught on, and the disease became known by her name for it.

By 1955 the society ‚Äì later known as the Royal Commonwealth Society of the Blind ‚Äì had set up national organisations in 20 countries, including Ghana, Nigeria, Barbados and Cyprus, which ran mobile eye clinics to treat river blindness, trachoma and other eye conditions. They also helped fund training schemes for blind farmers, ophthalmic surveys and educational projects. It was not a ‚Äútop down‚Äù organisation: instead, the Wilsons wanted to partner and support local initiatives.

Jean had trained as a teacher, and was particularly interested in educating blind children. She had visited schools in America that integrated children with sight loss into ordinary schools and helped set up a similar school in Uganda, but was dismayed that parents often thought a blind child was not worth educating.

Something dramatic was required to show how much blind people could achieve, and in 1969 the society arranged for seven blind men from Uganda, Kenya and Tanzania to climb Kilimanjaro. The expedition was covered widely by African newspapers and helped to convince parents that it was worth allowing their blind child to attend school.

John was knighted in 1975, bringing Jean the courtesy title of Lady Wilson. She was made OBE in 1981, and two years later they both

stepped down from Sightsavers, deciding to use their experience to tackle disability more widely. In 1981 Wilson had organised the Leeds Castle international seminar on the prevention of disablement as part of the United Nations‚Äô International Year of Disabled Persons.

After this, the Wilsons and their daughter Claire Hicks set up Impact in 1985 to address the whole spectrum of disability, including sight and hearing loss, physical disability and other conditions. Like Sightsavers, Impact partners with local organisations; in a flagship project in 1991, it collaborated with Indian Railways to launch the Lifeline Express, the world‚Äôs first hospital train. Last year alone nearly one million people benefited from Impact‚Äôs programmes.

Wilson passionately believed that much disability could be avoided through education and immunisation. The disease rubella during pregnancy can result in blindness and deafness in unborn babies, and in 1983 she became chair of the UK‚Äôs National Rubella Council, which ran education programmes to increase uptake of the rubella vaccine. She recruited prominent women such as Diana, Princess of Wales and Linda McCartney to publicise the campaign, and in four years they significantly increased rates of vaccination among women and girls.

Born in Acton, west London, Jean was the only child of Chloe (nee Byway) and John McDermid, and attended Harrow county school for girls. Her father worked in public health for Kensington and Chelsea borough council, but he died when she was 16. To make ends meet her mother took in lodgers, one of whom was John Wilson.

From 1941 to 1944 Jean studied history at Westfield College, University of London, which during the war had temporarily relocated to Oxford. She followed this with a teaching diploma at the London Institute of Education in 1945. She and John initially lived in London on the Finchley Road, where she had Claire in 1948 and Jane in 1953. In 1955 the family moved to a house near Rottingdean in Sussex, which was Jean‚Äôs base for the rest of her life and where she loved to garden.

John died in 1999. He had chaired the Hearing Conservation Council and Jean took over as chair. She also remained closely associated with her charities, serving as vice-president of Sightsavers and honorary president of Impact to the end of her life, and she continued to travel widely into her 90s. In 2002 she was made an honorary fellow of the Royal College of Ophthalmology.

She is survived by Claire, Jane, five grandchildren and eight great-grandchildren.

‚Ä¢ Chloe Jean Wilson, blindness and disability campaigner, born 17 August 1922; died 5 January 2026
subtitle: Co-founder of the charity Sightsavers and tireless campaigner for the education of blind children

title: US to offer passport services to citizens in illegal West Bank settlements
content:
The US will provide on-site consular services in two Israeli settlements in the occupied West Bank for the first time, breaking with previous policy, in a move that has been criticised by Palestinian officials as ‚Äúa clear violation of international law‚Äù.

In a post on X, the US embassy in Jerusalem said that as part of an initiative to mark the 250th anniversary of US independence, it would provide Americans with routine passport services in the West Bank settlement of Efrat on Friday ‚Äúfor one day only‚Äù.

Israeli settlements in the West Bank, which Israel has occupied since 1967, are illegal under international law. Efrat, about 7 miles (12km) south of Jerusalem, is home to about 12,000 Israelis.

The Palestinian Authority‚Äôs Colonization and Wall Resistance Commission said in a statement that the initiative ‚Äúconstitutes a clear violation of international law and a blatant favouring of the occupation authorities‚Äù, referring to Israel.

Mu‚Äôayyad Shaa‚Äôban, the head of the commission, said the step ‚Äúentrenches a settlement reality that undermines the possibility of establishing an independent and sovereign Palestinian state‚Äù.

Hamas called it ‚Äúa dangerous precedent‚Äù and a ‚Äúpractical recognition of the legitimacy of settlement and the occupation‚Äôs control over the West Bank‚Äù.

The US embassy in Jerusalem said similar facilities offering consular services would be provided in the coming months in a second Israeli settlement, Beitar Illit, as well as in the Palestinian city of Ramallah and three cities inside Israel.

The Israeli foreign minister, Gideon Saar, welcomed the US move. ‚ÄúWe ‚Ä¶ appreciate the important decision by the US embassy to extend consular services to Efrat, in Judea and Samaria,‚Äù he said, using the biblical name for the West Bank.

Hugh Lovatt, a senior policy fellow with the Middle East and North Africa programme at the European Council on Foreign Relations, said the intent and context of the new policy were important.

Related: Huckabee‚Äôs Israel land remarks condemned as ‚Äòdangerous and inflammatory‚Äô

‚ÄúThe background is very clear. Mike Huckabee [the US ambassador to Israel] is an avowed proponent of the Greater Israel vision and supports the realisation of that vision between the Jordan River and the Mediterranean Sea,‚Äù Lovatt said. ‚ÄúThis is a signal that the US will not treat the Israeli settlements [in the West Bank] in any different way from towns within Israel.‚Äù

Last week Israel‚Äôs cabinet approved measures to tighten the country‚Äôs control over the West Bank and make it easier for settlers to buy land, a move Palestinians called a ‚Äúde facto annexation‚Äù.

Donald Trump, a staunch supporter of Israel, has said he opposes Israeli annexation of the West Bank in line with longstanding US policy but his administration has not taken any measures to halt settlement activity, which has risen since he took office last year.

Settler violence and army raids have increased in the West Bank since the war in Gaza began in October 2023. Last week Israeli settlers shot and killed a Palestinian American man during an attack on a village, the Palestinian health ministry and a witness said.

On Tuesday there were arson attacks on Palestinian homes in Masafer Yatta and other nearby villages in the south Hebron Hills. The area has been repeatedly targeted by violent settlers in recent years.

The US currently offers passport and consular services at its embassy in Jerusalem as well as at a Tel Aviv branch office. The number of dual American-Israeli nationals living in the West Bank is estimated to be in the tens of thousands.

Much of the West Bank is under Israeli military control, with limited Palestinian self-rule in some areas run by the western-backed Palestinian Authority.

Netanyahu‚Äôs ruling coalition, which has a large voter base in the settlements, includes many members who want Israel to annex the West Bank, land captured in the 1967 Middle East war to which Israel cites biblical and historical ties.

Efrat, the Jewish settlement where American consular officials will provide passport services on Friday, is home to many American immigrants.

More than 500,000 Israeli settlers live in the West Bank, home to 3 million Palestinians. Most settlements are small towns surrounded by fences and guarded by Israeli soldiers.
subtitle: Israel welcomes move described by Palestinian Authority as undermining possibility of an independent state

title: Iceland to hold referendum on EU accession talks in next few months, PM says ‚Äì as it happened
content:
5.24pm GMT

Closing summary

‚Ä¶ and on that note, it‚Äôs a wrap for today!

  • Iceland is to hold a referendum on opening accession talks to join the European Union in ‚Äúthe next few months,‚Äù the country‚Äôs prime minister Kristr√∫n Frostad√≥ttir said (17:18).

  • Her comments appear to suggest the government will bring forward plans to organise the vote, previously rumoured to be planned for early 2027 (17:37).

In other news,

  • Hungarian prime minister Viktor Orb√°n appeared to escalate his rhetoric towards Ukraine (14:32) as he made unsubstantiated claims alleging that Ukraine could be looking to disrupt its energy grid, and ordered soldiers to protect key energy facilities (12:54), just weeks before a closely contested parliamentary election in Hungary.

  • The two countries remain at odds over their views on what is blocking the use of the Druzhba oil pipeline, which continues to be affected by recent Russian strikes (12:54, 13:06, 13:12).

Separately,

  • German chancellor Friedrich Merz for deepening ties with China, while pushing for fairer trade rules between the two countries and seeking Chinese help on Ukraine as he continues his visit to the country (9:51, 11:56).

  • Switzerland and the European Union will next week sign a package of agreements aimed at simplifying and harmonising their ties, Berne and Brussels said (13:50).

  • The 76th Sanremo Italian song festival got under way last night at the iconic Ariston Theatre (12:37).

And that‚Äôs all from me, Jakub Krupa, for today.

If you have any tips, comments or suggestions, email me at jakub.krupa@theguardian.com.

I am also on Bluesky at @jakubkrupa.bsky.social and on X at @jakubkrupa.

4.37pm GMT

The Icelandic referendum had previously been tipped for early 2027, so today‚Äôs comments from Frostad√≥ttir appear to confirm some media reporting that the government will try to bring it forward.

The formal proposal ‚Äì expected to be drafted early spring, according to local media ‚Äì needs to be approved by the parliament first, after which there is a nine-month window for organising the actual vote.

The Icelandic National Broadcasting Service said in January that two opinion polls appeared to indicate a narrow preference for joining the bloc, but with the margins so thin that it could go either way.

‚ÄúTwo opinion poll surveys in 2025 suggested slim majorities for those who favour EU membership. In one by Pr√≥sent, 45% of respondents said they supported Iceland‚Äôs accession to the European Union, while 35% said they did not. A Gallup survey from the same year suggested similar results, with 44% of respondents saying they favoured Iceland joining the European Union, and 36% saying they were opposed.‚Äù

Updated at 4.45pm GMT

4.18pm GMT

Iceland to hold referendum on opening EU accession talks in 'next few months,' PM says

Iceland is to hold a referendum on opening accession talks to join the European Union in ‚Äúthe next few months,‚Äù the country‚Äôs prime minister Kristr√∫n Frostad√≥ttir said at a press conference in Warsaw.

Speaking alongside the Polish prime minister, Donald Tusk, she said that the government ‚Äúhas not decided finally on the date‚Äù yet, but it is going to be ‚Äúin the coming months.‚Äù

‚ÄúWe are going forward now in the next few months ‚Äì possibly, as we haven‚Äôt decided finally on the date, but in the coming months ‚Ä¶ ‚Äì to have a referendum on opening up the accession negotiations for Iceland for possibly joining the EU,‚Äù she said.

She added that during her bilateral talks with Tusk, the pair ‚Äútalked extensively about the importance of understanding that this is about opening an opportunity‚Äù and integrating Iceland more with the EU, while preserving ‚Äúthe respect for Icelandic identity within Europe.‚Äù

She said it would be important for Iceland to see that its distinct Arctic identity is ‚Äútaken into consideration,‚Äù as well as its own ‚Äúway of life or the way we use our resources.‚Äù

Tusk said he would be ‚Äúmore than happy‚Äù to see Iceland join the bloc, drawing on Poland‚Äôs experience as a ‚Äúsuccess story‚Äù in the European integration.

He also agreed with Frostad√≥ttir on the importance of making sure the EU ‚Äúshow respect‚Äù to all countries and ‚Äútreat bigger and smaller countries equally.‚Äù

‚ÄúI would be more than happy if Iceland [joined] part of our community, even if [the EU] needed to change a little bit for that, be more flexible, and I would be ready to work with Kristr√∫n on this [as] it is in our common interest,‚Äù he said.

Tusk also drew on his personal experience of Britain‚Äôs withdrawal from the European Union, pointing to the shifting attitudes in the British society ten years on from the Brexit referendum as the evidence of belated appreciation of the value of the EU membership.

‚ÄúMaybe the best evidence that it makes sense to discuss integration is the situation in the UK. If you ask people ‚Ä¶ about Brexit ‚Ä¶ the latest polls are absolutely clear that 65% of the Brits would vote for the EU today; more than 80% of young people in the UK are in favour of a possible membership of the EU. [So,] if you have this very experience of Brexit, maybe you know much better than others that the membership of the EU is something really valuable,‚Äù he said.

Responding, Frostad√≥ttir diplomatically said that her government would ‚Äúlisten to whatever the Icelandic population wants to do,‚Äù but thanked him for his comments acknowledging Iceland‚Äôs own identity.

Some 30,000 Poles live in Iceland, making them by far the largest foreign born community in the country, with Frostad√≥ttir somewhat touchingly paying tribute to their contribution and singling out her daughter‚Äôs ‚Äúfavourite teacher in the kindergarten‚Äù named Ma≈Çgorzata.

As a gift, Frostad√≥ttir was also given a Polish chocolate wafer bar Prince Polo, which is very popular in Iceland ‚Äì and apparently is her dad‚Äôs favourite sweet snack.

Updated at 4.29pm GMT

3.07pm GMT

Germany 'appalled by Hungary's behaviour'

Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n is no stranger to criticism and the foreign ministers of Germany and Belgium have been laying it on thick.

‚ÄúAll I can say is that I remain appalled by Hungary‚Äôs behaviour,‚Äù said Germany‚Äôs Johann Wadephul, after Orb√°n blocked a major EU loan to Ukraine. He added that Hungary‚Äôs decision to veto the latest round of EU sanctions against Russia ‚Äúbetrays its own struggle for freedom‚Äù.

Belgian foreign minister Maxime Prevot also warned that ‚ÄúHungary must understand‚Äù that for other EU countries ‚Äúthe patience is wearing thin very quickly‚Äù.

2.42pm GMT

First Ukrainian drone plant in UK begins operations

Some news closer to home ‚Äì the first Ukrainian drone production plant in the UK has begun its operations today.

Valerii Zaluzhnyi, Ukraine‚Äôs ambassador to the UK and former commander of the Ukrainian armed forces, made the announcement on social media, saying launching production in the UK ‚Äúhas a deep strategic logic‚Äù.

He said:

This is not a shift in the centre of gravity from Ukraine. This is an expansion of our joint capabilities and the creation of a second resilience contour that guarantees the continuity of production.

We are leaving the engineering expertise centre in Ukraine and integrating production into the British defence space. We are creating a new quality of partnership, where allies not only support each other, but also form a common industrial security base.

The drones manufactured by Ukrainian company Ukrspecsystems ‚Äúhave long proven their effectiveness in hi-tech warfare‚Äù, Zaluzhnyi added.

He does not say where the plant is based, but Ukrspecsystems said in September that it would establish a production and training hub in Suffolk.

Both Ukraine and Russia have utilised drones on an unprecedented scale in the now four-year war, filling a gap left by a shortage of artillery and precision weapons.

Updated at 2.50pm GMT

2.06pm GMT

Former Polish intelligence chiefs face charges over Pegasus spyware

Former chiefs of Poland‚Äôs civil and military intelligence services face charges of misconduct in public office as part of a wider investigation into the previous government‚Äôs use of the controversial spyware Pegasus.

Pegasus is a powerful tool designed by Israeli company NSO Group. It is capable of taking control of a target‚Äôs mobile phone, accessing data from secure messaging apps and even turning the device into a recorder.

The two men, who led Poland‚Äôs Internal Security Agency and Military Counterintelligence Service, were charged on Wednesday, Poland‚Äôs prosecutor general said in a statement.

The prosecutors allege, among others, that they allowed for the spyware‚Äôs deployment despite not securing the high-level clearances required for intelligence operations. They could face up to three years in jail, the statement said.

For more on the domestic political controversies about the use of Pegasus, see Shaun Walker‚Äôs story from 2024:

Related: Poland launches inquiry into previous government‚Äôs spyware use

Updated at 2.11pm GMT

1.32pm GMT

Orb√°n doubles down on attacks on Ukraine, EU, Hungarian opposition ahead of key elections

Meanwhile, Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n has doubled down on his rhethoric against Ukraine and the EU, claiming in a highly-confrontational social media post that ‚Äúthe Brusselian leaders‚Äù ‚Äì his derisive term for top EU officials ‚Äì ‚Äúreached an agreement with president Zelenskyy to continue the war.‚Äù

‚ÄúThis is bad news for Europe. A war is being prolonged that clearly has no solution on the battlefield, yet causes immense destruction,‚Äù he said, stressing the high death toll of the conflict.

‚ÄúThis is what Brussels is supporting,‚Äù he claimed.

The pro-Russian leader, believed to be at risk of losing power after 16 years in the upcoming parliamentary election, claimed that Ukraine and Europe were losing the war, and unnecessarily provoking Russia into a nuclear confrontation ‚Äì essentially repeating some of the most recent Kremlin lines (Europe Live, Tuesday).

He further made further allegations ‚Äì without any evidence ‚Äì that during the recent Munich Security Conference the leader of the Hungarian opposition Tisza party, P√©ter Magyar, concluded ‚Äúa secret deal‚Äù with the EU, ‚Äúunder German patronage‚Äù and offered his support for the war.

‚ÄúHungary must stay out of this. The Hungarian government must safeguard the country‚Äôs security,‚Äù he said.

His comments need to be seen through the lens of the upcoming election in April, with polls suggesting Orb√°n is trailing behind Magyar‚Äôs Tisza by 10 percentage points, as he is seeking to ramp up his anti-Ukrainian rhetoric in a bid to make electoral gains.

12.50pm GMT

Switzerland and EU to finalise package of deals next week

Meanwhile, Switzerland and the European Union will next week sign a package of agreements aimed at simplifying and harmonising their ties, Berne and Brussels said, as reported by AFP.

The Swiss government said in a statement that it had been informed Wednesday that Swiss president Guy Parmelin and European Commission chief Ursula von der Leyen ‚Äúwould sign the Switzerland-EU package of agreements (Bilaterals III) in Brussels on Monday.‚Äù

EU-Swiss ties are currently governed by a patchwork of agreements, and the two have for years been striving to nail down a broader cooperation agreement. Switzerland suddenly walked away from more than a decade of negotiations in May 2021, but the two sides picked up talks again three years later, AFP explained.

‚ÄúSwitzerland and the EU will now sign the remaining agreements and protocols on 2 March, together with a joint declaration establishing a high-level dialogue,‚Äù Berne said.

The deal will still have to be voted on by the parliament and approved in a referendum, though.

12.27pm GMT

EU exporters could face months of uncertainty on trade with US

in Brussels

Exporters from the EU may face months of uncertainty selling products to the US with some manufacturers now facing higher tariffs than they did under the deal sealed last August with Donald Trump.

European trade commissioner Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç said on Tuesday the EU said it was facing ‚Äútransitional period‚Äù of a few months in relations with the US with commitments from trade representative Jamieson Greer and commerce secretary Howard Lutnick that they stood by last year‚Äôs agreement.

≈†efƒçoviƒç yesterday said the transition period could last 150 days, up to 24 July, when Trump‚Äôs latest 10% tariffs apply.

The EU‚Äôs trade spokesperson Olof Gill said today that Brussels was waiting to hear how that would transition would play out after the agreement involving tariffs of 15% on most exports was shot down by the US supreme court.

‚ÄúIf the US has given commitment that it will honour its agreements, that it will honour the 15%, we are waiting for them to explain in peer operational detail how that will work.

As regards the legal basis [of the current and future deal], that‚Äôs what the Americans have to explain to us. So we have this transitional phase ‚Ä¶ We are engaging with the US to ensure that in that transitional phase the commitments made by the US or the joint statements are honoured.

We will continue on our commitments, and in the meantime, there‚Äôs this deadline within which the US has to explain what comes next.‚Äù

The EU also confirmed that some goods that were tariffed at more than 5% before the deal would now face tariffs of more than 15%.

12.12pm GMT

Ukraine officials showed evidence of Russian damage to Druzhba pipeline, Poland's Sikorski says

For what it‚Äôs worth, Poland‚Äôs foreign minister Rados≈Çaw Sikorski said that during his visit to Kyiv on Tuesday, ‚Äúthe head of Ukraine‚Äôs Naftohaz showed me pictures of Russian damage to the Brody pumping station on the Druzhba oil pipeline,‚Äù siding with the Ukrainian explanation of the situation.

Updated at 12.23pm GMT

12.06pm GMT

Repair works on Druzhba pipeline ongoing but in 'very difficult circumstances' amid Russian attacks, Ukraine tells EU

Meanwhile, the European Commission said it was told by Ukraine that its efforts to repair the Druzhba oil pipeline connecting Siberian oilfields with central Europe were being hampered by heavy bombardment from Russia.

The commission‚Äôs president, Ursula von der Leyen, asked Ukraine to ‚Äúaccelerate‚Äù the works during her visit to Kyiv earlier this week.

But Ukraine told the European Commission that ‚Äúemergency preparatory work is ongoing, but in very difficult circumstances,‚Äù an EU spokesperson said.

‚ÄúWe understand the point of view of President Zelenskyy, who says that the Ukrainian people are constantly repairing what Russia is systematically destroying, and some citizens are even losing their lives, [while] repairing critical energy infrastructure,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúWe condemn in the strongest terms Russian attacks on Ukraine‚Äôs energy infrastructure,‚Äù she added.

11.54am GMT

Orb√°n alleges Ukraine could seek to disrupt Hungary's energy system

And in the last few minutes, Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n has escalated this conflict with Ukraine even further, claiming that Kyiv could be looking to ‚Äúdisrupt‚Äù the operation of Hungary‚Äôs energy system.

He offered no evidence to support the claim, but said that Hungary would deploy soldiers and equipment to protect key energy facilities.

The move comes as Orb√°n seeks to make his fiercly anti-Ukrainian stance one of the key points ahead of the key parliamentary election in April, which could see him ousted after 16 years in power.

11.54am GMT

Repairing Druzhba pipeline 'not that fast,' Zelenskyy says

President Volodymyr Zelenskyy said that Ukraine was looking to repair the Druzhba oil pipeline but ‚Äúit was not so fast,‚Äù Reuters reported.

Shipments of Russian oil to Hungary and Slovakia have been cut off since 27 January, when Kyiv says a Russian strike hit pipeline equipment in western Ukraine.

Slovakia and Hungary say Ukraine is to blame for the prolonged outage, with the Hungarian government moving to block the EU‚Äôs ‚Ç¨90bn loan for Kyiv and the 20th package of sanctions in response (9:51).

11.40am GMT

Right, let‚Äôs back to more serious news.

Updated at 12.04pm GMT

11.37am GMT

76th Italian song festival Sanremo gets under way

Now for something slightly different ‚Äì and perhaps even a bit uplifting (we all need it these days, don‚Äôt we!).

The 76th Sanremo Italian song festival got under way last night at the iconic Ariston Theatre, with a lineup of 30 performers taking to the stage to show their songs for this year.

Now, you could theoretically say it‚Äôs the Italian national final for the Eurovision song contest ‚Äì the winner gets (usually, but not always) to represent Italy there ‚Äì but you would do it entirely at your own risk of being angrily shouted at by the festival‚Äôs lovers, as Sanremo is essentially the original Eurovision, created five years before the ESC.

Cue five days of chaotic, super-lengthy nights of music (last night‚Äôs concert ended at half two in the morning, and it was still ahead of schedule) and an incredibly complicated format, taking place in February, on the Italian riviera. What‚Äôs not to like!?

The festival also includes an extensive lineup of co-hosts (this year it‚Äôs Laura Pausini) and guests, as well as number of, sometimes confusing (presumably only for non-Italian audience, or at least hopefully), sometimes genuinely moving segments touching on Italy‚Äôs history and pop culture.

One of them last night saw 105-year-old Gianna Pratesi appear in a touching segment remembering the 1946 Italian referendum to replace the monarchy with a republic, 80 years on.

Related: Italy: the birth of the republic ‚Äì archive, 11 June 1946

The host broadcaster, Italy‚Äôs Rai, has now published all songs performing in the contest on their YouTube so if you want some Italian pop, rock, what-the-hell-was-that and romantic songs in your life, you can catch up with the action here and last night‚Äôs (fittingly, very confusingly edited) highlights are here.

Eight songs from the competition went straight into Italy‚Äôs top 20 on YouTube, and there‚Äôs no doubt more to come as the week progresses.

You can watch it live everywhere as Rai has removed geoblock from its streaming platform, and the second night starts 8.40pm local time tonight.

Just saying.

Updated at 11.38am GMT

10.56am GMT

Germany's Merz looks for opportunities with China, despite differences

German chancellor Friedrich Merz called Wednesday for deepening ties with China, while pushing for fairer trade rules between the two countries and seeking Chinese help on Ukraine, AP reported.

Merz, who arrived in Beijing late morning for a whirlwind two-day visit, acknowledged differences during meetings with the country‚Äôs top leaders and called for collaboration ‚Äúwherever possible.‚Äù

The chancellor told China‚Äôs president Xi Jinping he saw ‚Äúgreat opportunity‚Äù to develop ties between their countries, as the two leaders met in Beijing, AFP said.

‚ÄúWe are two of the world‚Äôs three largest industrial nations. This is a great responsibility. But it is also a great opportunity,‚Äù Merz said.

‚ÄúI am willing to work together with the chancellor to jointly make efforts to continuously advance the comprehensive strategic partnership between China and Germany to new levels,‚Äù Xi responded, adding that he ‚Äúalways attached great importance to Sino-German relations‚Äù.

10.35am GMT

Macron names new Louvre head to get it out of crisis after last year's jewel heist

French president Emmanuel Macron has appointed Christophe Leribault, the current head of the Versailles Palace, as director of the Louvre museum in Paris, the French government spokesperson said, as reported by Reuters.

The move comes after the previous head of the museum resigned on Tuesday, four months after a gang of thieves broke into the museum‚Äôs Apollo gallery and made off with ‚Ç¨88m (¬£76m) of Napoleonic jewellery in France‚Äôs most dramatic heist in decades.

Related: Louvre president resigns as jewellery heist inquiry reveals ‚Äòsystemic failures‚Äô

10.17am GMT

EU-UK post-Brexit reset needs to be 'decisively accelerated,' senior MEP says

The ‚Äúreset‚Äù of post-Brexit relations between the UK and the EU must be ‚Äúdecisively accelerated‚Äù and given a ‚Äúsuper charge‚Äù to speed up links between the two sides, the co-chair of the EU-UK parliamentary partnership has said.

Ahead of the visit to London of the European parliament president Roberta Metsola, Sandro Gozi, MEP said:

‚ÄúProgress has been too slow. The EU-UK reset must now be supercharged. Engagement, based on respect of the Union‚Äôs principles, should be broadened and accelerated ahead of this summer‚Äôs EU-UK Summit.‚Äù

His comments come just hours after trade commissioner and European Commission vice-president Maro≈° ≈†efƒçoviƒç indicated that the next EU-UK summit may not be held until July, more than a year after the inaugural summit in London last May (Europe Live, Tuesday).

Gozi added that it was now almost 10 years since the referendum on Brexit and it was ‚Äútime for the UK government to recognise that the EU is Britain‚Äôs closest partner for sustainable economic growth‚Äù.

‚ÄúWe would like to see a reset from the UK that is commensurate with the scale of the challenges we face as Europeans. Ireland, Europe and the UK stand to benefit from greater ambition and from reducing trade barriers that remain unnecessarily high.‚Äù

9.56am GMT

Ukraine-US talks in Geneva on Thursday part of preparation for trilateral meeting with Russia, Zelenskyy says

In further comments on the state of peace talks, Zelenskyy also said that this Thursday‚Äôs meeting will be part of ‚Äúpreparations for a trilateral meeting with Russia, which we believe will take place in early March‚Äù.

Other issues on the agenda for Thursday are prisoner-of-war exchanges and a ‚Äúprosperity package‚Äù for the reconstruction of Ukraine, Zelensky said.

Witkoff confirmed the talks earlier this week saying the aim was to ‚Äúexplore different iterations about how we might get to a peace deal,‚Äù AFP reported.

9.25am GMT

'Working very hard' on Ukraine and pointed praise for Nato's defence spending ramp up in Trump's speech

If you expected some big lines on Ukraine or Europe from Trump‚Äôs State of the Union address overnight, well, there was hardly anything ‚Äì but he did speak positively about Nato.

Here are the key bits, via this NPR transcript of his speech.

On Nato:

Nato countries, our friends and allies, and they are -- they‚Äôre our friends and they‚Äôre our allies, have just agreed at my very strong request to pay 5 percent of GDP for military defence rather than the 2 percent, which they weren‚Äôt paying; we were paying for almost all of them. ‚Ä¶ Now they‚Äôre paying five as opposed to not paying for it. ‚Ä¶ And getting that 5 percent was something which everyone said would never be done, could not happen. We got it really easily with one meeting and [it‚Äôs] a big difference between 2 percent that‚Äôs not paid.

We were paying the freight of many of them. Very few were paid out. Now 5 percent then they‚Äôre paid. And everything we send over to Ukraine is sent through Nato and they pay us in full. They pay us totally in full.

On Ukraine:

‚ÄúAnd we‚Äôre working very hard to end the ninth war, the killing and slaughter between Russia and Ukraine, where 25,000 soldiers are dying each and every month.

Think of that, 25,000 soldiers are dying a month. A war which would have never happened if I were president, would have never happened. As president, I will make peace wherever I can, but I will never hesitate to confront threats to America wherever we must.‚Äù

Trump also paid tribute to a Ukrainian refugee killed in Charlotte last year, Iryna Zarutska.

Related: Maga is funding murals of a slain Ukrainian refugee. Are they weaponizing her memory?

9.06am GMT

Ukrainian negotiators to meet with US representatives on Thursday, Zelenskyy says

We are getting a line from Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy, telling reporters that Ukraine‚Äôs negotiators are expected to meet with US representatives on Thursday, as they continue to look for ways to end the Russian aggression on the country, a day after the fourth anniversary, Reuters reported.

8.51am GMT

Morning opening

The European Union continues to look for ways to get around Hungary‚Äôs block on the latest round of sanctions against Russia and on the release of the ‚Ç¨90bn loan to Ukraine.

The European Commission president, Ursula von der Leyen, said yesterday in Kyiv:

‚ÄúThe loan was agreed by 27 heads of state and government in the European Council, they have given their word. This word cannot be broken, so we will deliver on the loan one way or the other.‚Äù

Well, they better get creative as there is no sign that Hungary‚Äôs Viktor Orb√°n is willing to drop his veto, six weeks before the key election which could see him ousted after 16 years in power.

Responding to a letter from the European Council president, Ant√≥nio Costa, who urged the Hungarian PM to stick by what was agreed in December, Orb√°n effectively told him ‚Äúno‚Äù as he ramped up the pressure on Ukraine to restart oil transit via the Druzhba pipeline (Kyiv says the disruption was caused by a Russian drone strike, and has nothing to do with them.)

‚ÄúWe take a decision financially favourable to Ukraine that I personally disapprove, then Ukraine creates an energy emergency situation in Hungary, and you ask me to pretend that nothing happened.‚Äù

Separately, the German chancellor, Friedrich Merz, is in Beijing today for talks on trade and security.

Joining the growing list of western leaders to visit China in recent months, he intends to use the trip to urge president Xi Jinping and prime minister Li Qiang, whom he met last night, to put further pressure on China‚Äôs ally Russia to end the war in Ukraine, among other things.

Lots of things for us to cover.

Oh, and if you need something to brighten your mood: it‚Äôs Sanremo week, everyone! I will come back to this later.

It‚Äôs Wednesday, 25 February 2026, it‚Äôs Jakub Krupa here, and this is Europe Live.

Good morning.

Updated at 8.55am GMT
subtitle: Date for referendum on opening talks to join the EU yet to be decided but will be ‚Äòin the coming months‚Äô, says Kristr√∫n Frostad√≥ttir

title: Trump delivered the longest State of the Union in history ‚Ä¶ and ran out of steam | Ted Widmer
content:
In fulfillment of clause 1 of section 3 in article II of the US constitution, Donald Trump duly gave Congress ‚ÄúInformation of the State of the Union‚Äù last night.

Information ‚Ä¶ and more information. At an hour and 47 minutes, this was the longest State of the Union address in history. As he has so often done in the past, Trump bobbed and weaved impressively (‚Äúthe weave‚Äù is his own term for his meandering speaking style). He zigged and zagged, taunting Democrats for much of the speech (he called Zohran Mamdani a ‚Äúcommunist‚Äù and took pot shots at Democrats throughout the night), while claiming to be a unifier when the mood struck.

He was alert at times, working the room like a borscht belt comic, calling out friends, delivering jabs to enemies ‚Äì the menacing Jerry Lewis of The King of Comedy. But for long stretches, he read robotically from the teleprompter, as if tired by the ordeal of going up to Capitol Hill.

To be sure, he had his work cut out. This was a major opportunity for a reset, a little more than half a year before the midterms. He needed one. Trump‚Äôs approval ratings have cratered in recent weeks, due to outrage over killings of American citizens by federal immigration agents, and an incoherent foreign policy that has confused his Maga base and alienated most of our traditional allies.

A president who once swore to avoid forever wars is now deeply enmeshed in Iran, where a US flotilla is prepared to launch airstrikes, and in the Caribbean. His ‚ÄúBoard of Peace‚Äù has failed to win over America‚Äôs closest allies, and threatens to degrade the United Nations and an international Pax Americana once created by Americans.

Related: Why the longest-ever State of the Union address was the most inconsequential

His tariff policy is deeply unpopular, among Republicans as well as Democrats, and there are signs of a ‚ÄúTrump slump‚Äù coming in, dragging down the economy. A recent report stated that the US has lost 108,000 manufacturing jobs in the last year, despite Trump‚Äôs promises that his tariffs would bring factories ‚Äúroaring back‚Äù.

In short, reality bites. Trump continues to lash out at enemies, and the previous administration, but it has been a year of Republican control and the American people can see clearly that he is not delivering. More than two-thirds of Americans ‚Äì 68% ‚Äì say that he hasn‚Äôt paid attention to important problems, and he is hemorrhaging independent voters. More than half of voters ‚Äì 57 % ‚Äì disapprove of his handling of the economy. He tried to claim that he inherited a bad economy, but that is easily disproven (the Economist called the US economy ‚Äúthe envy of the world‚Äù in October 2024).

Trump came into the Capitol hoping to distract from these problems, and to an extent, he did. There were the usual cultural attacks, and more than a few ‚ÄúLenny Skutniks‚Äù, the name given to an outside hero figure (after a precedent created by Ronald Reagan in 1982, honoring a civilian who jumped into a frozen Potomac to rescue a plane crash survivor). In this case, the members of the US men‚Äôs hockey team, who were cheered lustily, were the marquee attraction. Trump also talked about American history, including the 250th anniversary celebration beginning this year, and the second world war (several veterans were in the chamber).

The result was a Bataan death march at times, and a long speech in search of a point

But the result was a Bataan death march at times, and a long speech in search of a point. The State of the Union address has been in decline for decades, as a TV spectacle, and Trump probably hastened that trend.

Can anyone remember a single one of his addresses from his first term? Tonight will be no different. He ignored topics of great relevance in the days ahead (Are we going to war in Iran? Can we say something to meaningful to Ukraine on the fourth anniversary of Putin‚Äôs invasion?), while meandering about private obsessions of dubious relevance.

He claimed that the US was the ‚Äúhottest‚Äù country while ignoring steep declines in favorability ratings. He denounced immigrants while failing to speak about a topic very much on the minds of Americans, the killing of Renee Good and Alex Pretti by federal immigration agents in Minneapolis. That omission feels all the more striking at a time when so many Americans are wondering about a justice system that seems rigged to reward the wealthy, and to forget everyone else, as in the Jeffrey Epstein case.

In other ways, too, ‚Äúthe weave‚Äù seemed to be running out of steam. At times, Trump seemed to think Nancy Pelosi was still speaker of the House. Far from ‚Äúdefeating‚Äù affordability, as he claimed, Trump seems overmatched by it. The price of hamburger is up 17.2% from a year ago. Coffee has increased by 18.3%. Nearly two-thirds of Americans ‚Äì 65% ‚Äì are unable to afford a median-priced home. The Trump-led expiration of healthcare subsidies will make healthcare unaffordable to millions. At the same time, the One Big Beautiful Bill Act delivered a trillion dollars in tax cuts to the top 1%.

Trump spoke often of 1776, and the beginning of the anniversary year. He is far from the first president to do so. But 1776 is also the year that Edward Gibbon wrote his classic History of the Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire. In that work, Gibbon wondered why a great people had allowed their civic institutions to wither. He then answered his own question.

They blamed anyone but themselves for their problems, usually fixating on foreigners. They abandoned their libraries and cultural institutions, and were drawn to ‚Äúcircuses and theatres‚Äù for sensational entertainments. They also tore down a lot of their better civic buildings. As Gibbon put it:

The monuments of consular, or Imperial, greatness were no longer revered, as the immortal glory of the capital: they were only esteemed as an inexhaustible mine of materials, cheaper, and more convenient than the distant quarry. Specious petitions were continually addressed to the easy magistrates of Rome, which stated the want of stones or bricks, for some necessary service: the fairest forms of architecture were rudely defaced, for the sake of some paltry, or pretended, repairs; and the degenerate Romans, who converted the spoil to their own emolument, demolished, with sacrilegious hands, the labors of their ancestors.

Sound familiar?

  • Ted Widmer is a historian and a former White House speechwriter (in the Clinton administration). He is the author of a forthcoming study of the Declaration of Independence, The Living Declaration: A Biography of America‚Äôs Founding Text, with the Library of America
subtitle: The State of the Union address has been in decline for decade as a TV spectacle, and Trump probably hastened that trend

title: Brazilian politician brothers convicted of ordering murder of Rio city councillor
content:
Two influential Brazilian politician brothers have been convicted by Brazil‚Äôs supreme court of ordering the murder of Marielle Franco, the Rio de Janeiro city councillor, nearly eight years ago.

Jo√£o Francisco In√°cio Braz√£o, the former congressman known as Chiquinho, and the former adviser to Rio‚Äôs court of auditors Domingos In√°cio Braz√£o were sentenced to 76 years and three months in prison for the murders of Franco, 38, and her driver, Anderson Gomes, 39.

The crime was one of the most shocking and high-profile murders in Rio‚Äôs history and drew international attention: Franco, a gay Black woman, was a rising political star and an outspoken critic of police violence and corruption.

The justices‚Äô decision was unanimous, and the Braz√£o brothers were also convicted of the attempted murder of Fernanda Chaves, Franco‚Äôs press officer at the time, who was in the car and survived.

Related: Who killed Marielle Franco? Arrests lay bare nexus of politicians, police and paramilitaries

The case is also widely seen by security experts and human rights activists as a chilling example of how the ties between politics, crime and the police are deeply entrenched in Rio, reaching even the highest levels of public administration.

Franco‚Äôs sister, Anielle Franco, wrote on social media: ‚ÄúIt was eight years of struggle to find out who ordered Marielle‚Äôs killing and why. It was eight years fighting for full justice.

‚ÄúToday Brazil‚Äôs justice system honoured the memory of Marielle and Anderson. Brazil begins a new historic chapter in confronting political violence based on gender and race. Impunity cannot be part of our democracy,‚Äù added Anielle, who is minister for racial equality in the government of Luiz In√°cio Lula da Silva.

Announcing her vote, Justice C√°rmen L√∫cia said the proceedings had been ‚Äúvery painful‚Äù for her.

‚ÄúHuman justice is not capable of soothing this pain. This trial is merely a timid, almost embarrassed testimony on my part of the response the law can offer in the face of the searing, atrocious pain borne on the faces of the mother, the daughter, the son, the widows,‚Äù added L√∫cia, referring to the relatives of Franco and Gomes, who were present in the courtroom.

The long journey of almost a decade to secure the convictions was marked by a tortuous series of twists that included the destruction of evidence, frequent changes in lead investigators and even the revelation that the then head of the homicide division, Rivaldo Barbosa, actively worked to obstruct the investigation.

Barbosa was not convicted of murder on Wednesday, as the justices found there was insufficient evidence that he had taken part in the killings, but he was found guilty on the lesser charges of obstruction of justice and corruption for having received bribes from the Braz√£o brothers.

The case was tried by the supreme court because Chiquinho was a congressman when his involvement was uncovered. The convictions came more than a year after two former police officers who carried out the killings were sentenced by a court in Rio.

Ronnie Lessa, who fired the shots in the drive-by shooting, and √âlcio de Queiroz, who drove the getaway car, were sentenced in October 2024 to decades in prison, but their sentences were reduced to a maximum of 30 years after they confessed and cooperated with investigators.

Lessa, regarded as one of Rio‚Äôs most ruthless hitmen, said he had been hired by the Braz√£o brothers ‚Äì long accused of involvement with paramilitary mafia groups known as militias ‚Äì to kill Franco after becoming frustrated by her efforts to disrupt lucrative housing development schemes.

‚ÄúMarielle Franco became a highly significant obstacle to the economic and political interests of those who ordered the crime,‚Äù said the rapporteur, Justice Alexandre de Moraes.
